text: , also called Kitano Tenjin-jinja and Kitano Temmangū, is a Shinto shrine in Kamigyō-ku, Kyoto, Japan.Nussbaum, Louis-Frédéric. (2005). "Kitano Tenjin- jinja" in Japan Encyclopedia, p. 531; Ponsonby-Fane, Richard. (1964) Visiting Famous Shrines in Japan, pp. 194-220. ==History== The shrine was built in 947, to appease the angry spirit of Sugawara no Michizane.Nussbaum, "Sugawara no Michizane," p. 908. He had been wrongly sent into exile.Smith, Roberta. "Unfurling a Thousand Years of Gods, Demons and Romance," New York Times. December 1, 2011; retreieved 2012-1-3. The shrine became the object of Imperial patronage during the early Heian period.Breen, John. (2000). Shinto in History: Ways of the Kami, pp. 74-75. The current buildings date from the early 17th century.Nussbaum, p. 531. ===Timeline=== * 965 (Kōhō 2): Emperor Murakami ordered that Imperial messengers be sent to report important events to the guardian kami of Japan. These messenger, called heihaku, were initially presented to 16 shrines;Ponsonby-Fane, Richard. (1962). Studies in Shinto and Shrines, pp. 116-117. * 986 (Kanna 2): Michizane was given the posthumous title of Tenjin (Heavenly Deity) * 991 (Shōryaku 2): Emperor Ichijō added three more shrines to Murakami's list -- including Kitano.Ponsonby-Fane, Studies in Shrines, p. 118. * 1444 (Bun'an 1, 4th month): Kitano Tenman-gū and much of western Kyoto was destroyed by fire.Titsingh, Isaac. (1834). Annales des empereurs du japon, p. 343. From 1871 through 1946, the Kitano Tenman-gū was officially designated one of the , meaning that it stood in the second rank of government supported shrines.Ponsonby-Fane, Richard. (1959).
